item.title: Discussion Night
item.description:
We are excited to announce our next event of the term, a philosophy discussion night in collaboration with the Wilfrid Laurier University Philosophy Club! The event will begin at 6pm with 30 minutes of philosophy themed games and icebreakers. From 6:30-8:30pm, we will break into groups to discuss philosophy questions.
The event is open to everyone of all majors/experience levels, and all topics or terminology will be briefly explained before each discussion begins to ensure everyone is on the same page.
WHEN: Thursday, October 30th 6pm-8:30pm WHERE: Laurier Campus, ARTS 2C17 (Arts C wing C)
As the discussion night will be held at Laurier University, we will post detailed instructions for how to get there before the event. The WLU interactive map can be found in our linktree.
If you would like to submit a discussion topic question ahead of time, you can do so through the form in our linktree.
We hope to see you there!

item.title: Guitar Workshop
item.description: JAMNETWORKIANS! Ever wanted to learn how to play the guitar? Or are you an intermediate player looking to advance your skills? IF SO, you should come to our guitar workshops happening this October 30th (Thursday)! Donâ€™t worry about not having a guitar, because WE are providing a variety of guitars to play on to all those who attend ðŸŽ¸ We will be having three types of guitar workshop stations ongoing starting at 8:00 :) This is a free event with no sign up required! ðŸ”¥ ðŸŽ¶ Feel free to bring your own guitar if you have one. âž¡ï¸ Beginner Station (Teachers: Brandon and Arayansh) Are you a beginner guitar player, and are looking to learn basic chords so you can play along to your favourite songs? Well, the beginner station is for you! At the beginner station lead by Brandon and Arayansh, you will learn basic strumming patterns, chords and playing technique in order to play your favourite songs! âž¡ï¸ Riff Creation Station (Teacher: Camilo) Do you want to make your own catchy melodies and SOLOS!!?? Well then the riff creation station is for you :) Camilo will teach you about creating your own melodies on top of chord progressions, lead guitar techniques, and other soloing tips! âž¡ï¸ Scale Station (Teacher: Matt) Do you want to understand what youâ€™re actually playing? Familarize yourself with patterns in the songs that you love? Check out the scale station where you will learn more scales than fish have... Use these shapes for solos, melodies, etc! You do not have to be an advanced guitar player for any of these stations! Just come with a willingness to learn!

item.title: Applying Mathematical Models to Vaccination and Epidemiology
item.description:
Our first AMATH Prof Talk of the term is coming up soon!
Title: Applying Mathematical Models to Vaccination and Epidemiology Speaker: Prof. Chris Bauch Abstract: Vaccine refusal has enabled previously eliminated infectious diseases--such as measles and pertussis--to re-emerge in many populations. Vaccine refusal is driven by many factors, one of which is the presence or absence of the infectious disease that the vaccine itself prevents. This suggests that disease spread and vaccine decision-making are, in fact, two parts of a single coupled system of behaviour-disease interactions. Mathematical models have a long history of application in the population biology of human pathogens, including pediatric infectious diseases, and they are increasingly applied to coupled behaviour-disease interactions as well. In this talk I will give an overview of some simple mathematical models of vaccine refusal for pediatric infectious diseases, including a discussion of what they predict and how well they match up with observational data. I will also discuss extensions of these models to the COVID pandemic.
Pizza and refreshments available for PMC members.

item.title: Law and Economics: Rational and Objective or Fundamentally Unjust?
item.description:
We are happy to announce our Philosophy Talk of the term presented by Professor Patricia Marino, Law and economics: rational and objective or fundamentally unjust?
WHEN: Wednesday November 5th at 5pm WHERE: Hagey Hall Room 345 DESCRIPTION: Law and economics is the application of economic theory to legal reasoning: in this increasingly influential approach, laws are understood not in terms of justice and rights, but rather as efficient solutions to the problems of organizing society. In normative law and economics, the aim of the legal system is to maximize social welfare. Normative law and economics thus echoes the ethical theory of utilitarianism, where the right action is the one that produces the best consequences. Like utilitarianism, law and economics reasoning faces challenges to do with ethical values such as justice, fairness, and equality: what if the best consequences sacrifice some people's interests for the good of others, increase inequality, or violate other ethical norms? In this talk, I showcase these problems through examples related to tax policy, environmental injustice, and health care resource allocation; I then explain how proponents of law and economics respond to these challenges. We can then discuss together whether law and economics is a rational, objective alternative to arbitrary decision-making or whether its recommendations can be fundamentally unjust.
Snacks and drinks will be provided. This talk is open to all members of the UW community, no experience or expertise in philosophy required. We hope to see you there for an interesting philosophy talk and discussion on philosophy of economics!

item.title: STANK: Serve's Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition
item.description: ðŸ¥§ Prepare for a Feast of Fierce Volleyball! ðŸ¦ƒ As the leaves turn and the holiday spirit fills the air, itâ€™s time for STANK: Serveâ€™s Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition! Letâ€™s celebrate the season with some friendly competition and a full plate of fun! Event Details: ðŸ Date: Saturday, November 15th-16th (Overnight) â° Time: 8pm to 8am ðŸ“ Location: PAC Main Gym + Small Gym ðŸ‚ Team Sign-Up Form your crew of 6 to 9 players (only UWaterloo students with a valid athletics membership or alumni with a day pass) and choose your division: semi-competitive or competitive. Co-ed rules apply: all teams must have at least 2 female-identifying players on the court at all times. (Note: A female libero is required to serve for a middle.) âš ï¸ NEW Semi-Comp Sign-Up Rules (Read Carefully!) To keep play balanced and fair this season: - Any male-identifying player rated Level 5 or of Level 5 ability must set or lib on a semi-comp team. - If you attended UW prior to the 5-level system (graduated before Fall 2023), the same rule applies if you were rated Level 4. - Spring levels are not included in this consideration. - If thereâ€™s any confusion, please reach out to an exec for clarification. - If your team has a Level 5 male player signed up for semi-comp, contact an exec to verify the validity of your team. - Players who are not evaluated this term may be removed from your team on the day of or asked to set/lib if necessary. ðŸ’° Pricing Regular (still fresh out of the coop): Register by Nov 3rd for $200 Both the form and payment must be completed by Nov 3rd @ 11:59pm. ðŸ“ How to Register Make your payment: https://warrior.uwaterloo.ca/Program/GetProgramDetails?courseId=e7072bd1-0754-4e99-9fbe-04a18228cfe1 Fill out the form: https://forms.office.com/r/twpLDkzmhD @everyone ðŸ Letâ€™s spice up the season, rally together, and make this Thanksgiving one to remember!

item.title: From Outages to Ownership
item.description:
From Outages to Ownership: Disaster Recovery, DNS, and Career Journeys in Okta Engineering
Ready to see how a top tech company handles the really big challenges? Join us and our Okta engineers for an evening focused on the critical work that keeps our services running; even when major outages happen. Our Staff Software Engineer will kick off the event with a fascinating technical talk, diving into DNS, redundancy, and disaster recovery based on her real-world experience at Okta. Itâ€™s a timely look at how engineering teams build for reliability at scale.
After the deep-dive, youâ€™ll hear from a panel of Engineers from various teams as they share their own career paths, offer a peek into their day-to-day work, and give you practical advice for launching your career. Stick around for our informal networking mixer to connect one-on-one with the team and ask any final questions!
ðŸ”— Link in bio to register
